title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu secures a second term as Boston mayor, running unopposed after opponent Josh Kraft exited in September.
Wu gains national attention after testifying to Congress, maintaining a 66% favorability rating as she begins her new term.
City Council President Ruthzee Loujieune and Councilor Henry Santana join Wu at election night party in Seaport restaurant.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Wu is unopposed in the election, set for a second term after key challengers dropped out.
Key issues during Wu's tenure include housing costs, climate goals, and maintaining Boston's 'sanctuary city' status.
Residents are invited to suggest priorities for Wu's upcoming term, including housing, climate, and public safety.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Nine Allston Car Wash employees with work permits were detained in a raid by ICE agents Tuesday morning.
The ICE agents, masked and armed with subpoenas, detained workers before they could present documents due to a language barrier.
Boston leaders condemned the ICE raid as unlawful, urging affected families to seek support from local immigration resources.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots chose not to make any trades at the NFL deadline, retaining their current roster.
Despite a 7-2 record and a six-game winning streak, the Patriots did not pursue blockbuster trades for immediate improvements.
Key areas like running back depth and pass-rushing remain concerns as the Patriots deal with injuries and limited roster changes.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston restaurants and food businesses offer meals and aid amid federal government shutdown and SNAP benefit cuts.
Allandale Farm and other local businesses set up programs offering free produce, bread, and meals for those affected by SNAP delays.
Federal judges ruled SNAP must use an emergency fund, but distribution timing and amounts remain uncertain amid the shutdown.

title: Karen Read shuffles defense attorney lineup in wrongful death suit
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Karen Read reshuffles her defense team in a civil wrongful death lawsuit filed by John O’Keefe’s family.
Attorneys from Melick & Porter withdrew from the case; lawyers from Tang & Maravelis have joined Read's defense.
Read was acquitted of murder in O’Keefe's case but plans to sue investigators for alleged conspiracy and civil rights violations.

title: FuGaKyu in Brookline closes after 27 years in business
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: FuGaKyu, a Japanese restaurant in Brookline, is closing on November 5 after 27 years in business.
Opened in 1998, FuGaKyu was known for its sushi and shoji decor; owner cited personal reasons for closure.
The restaurant had former locations in Lynnfield and Sudbury; patrons shared memories on social media following closure announcement.

title: Halsey hospitalized with ‘minor medical emergency’ in between Boston shows
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Halsey was hospitalized for a 'minor medical emergency' between two sold-out shows at MGM Music Hall in Boston.
She praised Massachusetts General Hospital staff, including Dr. Kian and Dr. Victoria, for their care during her hospital visit.
The artist, known for her health challenges, returned to perform on time for her 'Back to Badlands' tour at Fenway.

title: 18-year-old killed in Belmont moped crash
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An 18-year-old Watertown man was killed in a moped crash in Belmont on Tuesday morning, authorities reported.
The crash occurred at Stults Road and Fairview Avenue after the moped collided with an SUV, leaving the rider dead.
The investigation into the crash involves Belmont police, the District Attorney's office, and Massachusetts State Police.

title: Feds: Nurse replaced liquid oxy with household cleaner
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Lori Robertson from Salem, NH, accused of replacing a patient's oxycodone with a household cleaner in Amesbury.
Robertson pleaded not guilty to tampering with a consumer product that affected interstate commerce, according to federal charges.
She was released on probation with conditions and is scheduled to appear in court on November 24 for a status conference.
